## Problem

This problem comes from [Project Euler 8](https://projecteuler.net/problem=8)

<div class="max-md:hidden">
{/* EXCERPT START */}
> **Problem**
>
> The four adjacent digits in the 1000-digit number that have the greatest product are <Math equation="9 \times 9 \times 8 \times 9 = 5832." />
>
> 73167176531330624919225119674426574742355349194934

>
> Find the thirteen adjacent digits in the 1000-digit number that have the greatest product. What is the value of this product?
{/* EXCERPT END */}
</div>

## Solution
We have to multiply 13 adjacent digits and find the largest. To do this we can use a "sliding window" to multiply an array of numbers.

![Sliding Window](/images/posts/project-euler/Slide_100.gif)

We multiply the first 13 numbers and check if it is greater than our previous maximum (our previous maximum is set to 0 initially). If it is, we store our new maximum. Then we slide our "window" over by one number, and then multiply *those* 13 numbers and check if it's greater than our previous maximum, and store the number if it is. We rinse and repeat until we reach the end of the 1000-digit number.

## Code

<Tab url="https://github.com/zlaast/Project-Euler/blob/main/Problems%20%5B1-100)/problem08.py" tab="problem08.py">
```python
# Project Euler: Problem 8
# Largest product in a series

import math

number = '''
73167176531330624919225119674426574742355349194934
96983520312774506326239578318016984801869478851843
85861560789112949495459501737958331952853208805511
12540698747158523863050715693290963295227443043557
66896648950445244523161731856403098711121722383113
62229893423380308135336276614282806444486645238749
30358907296290491560440772390713810515859307960866
70172427121883998797908792274921901699720888093776
65727333001053367881220235421809751254540594752243
52584907711670556013604839586446706324415722155397
53697817977846174064955149290862569321978468622482
83972241375657056057490261407972968652414535100474
82166370484403199890008895243450658541227588666881
16427171479924442928230863465674813919123162824586
17866458359124566529476545682848912883142607690042
24219022671055626321111109370544217506941658960408
07198403850962455444362981230987879927244284909188
84580156166097919133875499200524063689912560717606
05886116467109405077541002256983155200055935729725
71636269561882670428252483600823257530420752963450
'''.replace('\n','')

number_list = [int(i) for i in number]

max = 0
for i in range (0, len(number_list)-13):
    product = math.prod(number_list[i:i+13])

    if (product > max):
        max = product

print(max)
```
</Tab>

I imported the number as a string so that I can convert it to a list (array) of integers. Then I iterate through the list with my sliding "window" (list slice) as mentioned in the previous section. I finally print the result.

**Note:** `math.prod()` requires a minimum version of Python 3.8 to work
